items.headline: fun SVG crime fact

markdown.content: you can fetch in other SVGs using Javascript (when in a new tab), and then eval JavaScript loaded inside those. this should also work for SVG in drafts, if you want to go full hosting via chost, and start using SVGs as libraries

items.plainTextBody: you can fetch in other SVGs using Javascript (when in a new tab), and then eval JavaScript loaded inside those. this should also work for SVG in drafts, if you want to go full hosting via chost, and start using SVGs as libraries

items.headline: getting more emulators to run (kind of) on cohost update

markdown.content: think i may have a way to port the gameboy to cohost (SVG again, oops) but i got distracted by playing about in GB Studio (real neat!!)
tomorrow i want to work on a proof of concept (posting a gameboy game to the timeline), then it'll be figuring out how the heck gameboy colour support works (gameboy palette stuff is a mystery to me)
from there, i'm hoping to build a snazzy tool, so you can drop a ROM file in and (using the cohost API wrappers we already have) Chost out your rom file so others can have a go.
dream at the end of this is a low friction way of sharing retro projects that still lets people on phones have a go at what you're doing, and with built in discussions and sharing below
anyway image attached is a little screenshot from the tutorial / demo file thingy i'm making
also catch me purchasing cohost plus tomorrow for the key feature of uploading strangely big SVG files
This Chost discusses SVG crimes.See previous SVG crimes

items.plainTextBody:
think i may have a way to port the gameboy to cohost (SVG again, oops) but i got distracted by playing about in GB Studio (real neat!!) tomorrow i want to work on a proof of concept (posting a gameboy game to the timeline), then it'll be figuring out how the heck gameboy colour support works (gameboy palette stuff is a mystery to me) from there, i'm hoping to build a snazzy tool, so you can drop a ROM file in and (using the cohost API wrappers we already have) Chost out your rom file so others can have a go. dream at the end of this is a low friction way of sharing retro projects that still lets people on phones have a go at what you're doing, and with built in discussions and sharing below anyway image attached is a little screenshot from the tutorial / demo file thingy i'm making also catch me purchasing cohost plus tomorrow for the key feature of uploading strangely big SVG files

shareTree.headline: A Gaming Industry

markdown.content: The first time I had to file taxes, I was faced with what I thought would be a pretty straight-forward question. What industry did I work in? Well, one of the options in the drop-down TurboTax gave me was 'Gaming'. Yep, I thought. I work as a certification tester for Nintendo of America, that's my industry. I did a little more digging, however, before realizing that they were referring to what was commonly known of as the Gaming Industry in the years far before the Nintendo Entertainment System hit shelves: casinos and gambling.

In the years since, I've come to understand the blanket term for my industry would be the Entertainment Industry. We collaboratively work towards creating something that is, ultimately, entertaining. Because if gaming is gambling, then entertainment is storytelling. So why do we conflate the two?

I read John Riccitiello's [interview](https://www.pocketgamer.biz/interview/79190/unity-ironsource-john-riccitiello-marc-whitten-merger/) talking about the recent and bizarre merger between Unity and malware distributor ironSource and was struck by the language used. Compulsion loop. Attrition rate. These are all terms I've heard before, especially working on a AAA MMO (in my case, Guild Wars 2). Monetization, when you're creating an essentially Forever Game (live game, service game, etc.), is the lifeblood of the game. But it also is what fuels what Riccitiello's talking about here: mobile game development. That's what Unity's all about lately, because that's where the money is. It's also something you can use to define developing a better slot machine. But we're digging into some very specific holes in conflating these worlds.

Regardless of the specific challenges and budgets required in making games, corporation-backed companies are in love with the idea of infinite money generators. And what better vehicle to create these things than a compelling video game? We loop through, we gain prizes, to enable us to loop through, to gain prizes. It's the same drive that keeps addicts returning to a casino. It's the odds stacking in their favor until they're ready to dive into the prize bucket and get a cement floor instead. Developers are entering into a world they think they know but are seeing that cement floor. Gacha games hit their marks on content-centric fandoms, create designs that spawn art, fiction, devotion. They draw in new crowds to insert money into the machine and hope that the concept of ownership stays compelling and fresh.

Every so often I have to force myself to take a step back and wonder at what my industry is. What am I creating content for? Where is my music going? It's something that becomes increasingly important because ultimately we've become lost in a blurring of definition. What Gaming Industry are we a part of?

I look at the state of arcades. Where once you could walk into a dark room full of machines willing to absorb your quarters for an experience and a score. There wasn't really much to gain except bragging rights, a leaderboard, fun. Entertainment. That's still there, to some degree. But the overgrowth of reward, earning, ownership, is a greater force today. Play a carnival game, get tickets. Exchange tickets for prizes. Gamble your skill. Get tangible rewards. Get something in exchange for your perception of skill, or luck.

Tech heads want to believe in ownership being the future of games. If you play, you earn. If you earn, you own. If you own, you are superior. The experience doesn't matter. The entertainment doesn't matter. Owning matters. Property matters. Who is doing the playing? Who is being entertained? Doesn't matter. Own things. Take a risk. Get a payout.
What industry are we a part of?

I like telling stories. I think a lot about how I had the choice to pursue writing, or animation, or some form of storytelling other than video games. Would I have been happier there? Are we better off telling our stories in a static medium? Maybe. With the direction corporations want to take this industry, maybe static is the better direction. But I do still think games are worth pursuing. I think there's experiences left to engage in that are only possible because of interaction. Is it a naive pursuit? We'll see, I guess.

shareTree.plainTextBody:
The first time I had to file taxes, I was faced with what I thought would be a pretty straight-forward question. What industry did I work in? Well, one of the options in the drop-down TurboTax gave me was 'Gaming'. Yep, I thought. I work as a certification tester for Nintendo of America, that's my industry. I did a little more digging, however, before realizing that they were referring to what was commonly known of as the Gaming Industry in the years far before the Nintendo Entertainment System hit shelves: casinos and gambling.

In the years since, I've come to understand the blanket term for my industry would be the Entertainment Industry. We collaboratively work towards creating something that is, ultimately, entertaining. Because if gaming is gambling, then entertainment is storytelling. So why do we conflate the two? 

I read John Riccitiello's [interview](https://www.pocketgamer.biz/interview/79190/unity-ironsource-john-riccitiello-marc-whitten-merger/) talking about the recent and bizarre merger between Unity and malware distributor ironSource and was struck by the language used. Compulsion loop. Attrition rate. These are all terms I've heard before, especially working on a AAA MMO (in my case, Guild Wars 2). Monetization, when you're creating an essentially Forever Game (live game, service game, etc.), is the lifeblood of the game. But it also is what fuels what Riccitiello's talking about here: mobile game development. That's what Unity's all about lately, because that's where the money is. It's also something you can use to define developing a better slot machine. But we're digging into some very specific holes in conflating these worlds.

Regardless of the specific challenges and budgets required in making games, corporation-backed companies are in love with the idea of infinite money generators. And what better vehicle to create these things than a compelling video game? We loop through, we gain prizes, to enable us to loop through, to gain prizes. It's the same drive that keeps addicts returning to a casino. It's the odds stacking in their favor until they're ready to dive into the prize bucket and get a cement floor instead. Developers are entering into a world they think they know but are seeing that cement floor. Gacha games hit their marks on content-centric fandoms, create designs that spawn art, fiction, devotion. They draw in new crowds to insert money into the machine and hope that the concept of ownership stays compelling and fresh.

Every so often I have to force myself to take a step back and wonder at what my industry is. What am I creating content for? Where is my music going? It's something that becomes increasingly important because ultimately we've become lost in a blurring of definition. What Gaming Industry are we a part of?

I look at the state of arcades. Where once you could walk into a dark room full of machines willing to absorb your quarters for an experience and a score. There wasn't really much to gain except bragging rights, a leaderboard, fun. Entertainment. That's still there, to some degree. But the overgrowth of reward, earning, ownership, is a greater force today. Play a carnival game, get tickets. Exchange tickets for prizes. Gamble your skill. Get tangible rewards. Get something in exchange for your perception of skill, or luck.

Tech heads want to believe in ownership being the future of games. If you play, you earn. If you earn, you own. If you own, you are superior. The experience doesn't matter. The entertainment doesn't matter. Owning matters. Property matters. Who is doing the playing? Who is being entertained? Doesn't matter. Own things. Take a risk. Get a payout. 

What industry are we a part of?

I like telling stories. I think a lot about how I had the choice to pursue writing, or animation, or some form of storytelling other than video games. Would I have been happier there? Are we better off telling our stories in a static medium? Maybe. With the direction corporations want to take this industry, maybe static is the better direction. But I do still think games are worth pursuing. I think there's experiences left to engage in that are only possible because of interaction. Is it a naive pursuit? We'll see, I guess.

items.headline: idea ??

markdown.content: hello !! so, for anyone who uses GB Studio and wants to share stuff to Cohost - would people be interested in a tool to upload a “cartridge”
idea is - as you can run Javascript inside an SVG (in a new tab) - an SVG which shows the game info on Cohost, which when opened in a new tab will launch the ROM file in an emulator
idea being easy sharing of little prototypes and projects, without external hosting !

items.plainTextBody:
hello !! so, for anyone who uses GB Studio and wants to share stuff to Cohost - would people be interested in a tool to upload a “cartridge”

idea is - as you can run Javascript inside an SVG (in a new tab) - an SVG which shows the game info on Cohost, which when opened in a new tab will launch the ROM file in an emulator

idea being easy sharing of little prototypes and projects, without external hosting !

shareTree.headline: updating the look & feel of the "adult content" content note

markdown.content: we got some feedback from nsfw artists that the content note for adult content (the thing you see after you click through to view an adult-content post) was too big and sounded too judgmental, so we shrunk it down to the bare essentials, which also links out to the knowledgebase article on the site's definition of adult content.  this change should be live in the next half-hour or so.

shareTree.headline: page and tag search is now live!

markdown.content: you can access it from the sidebar! we'll be making improvements to the overall UX and design and would appreciate any feedback you have! aidan's out on vacation this week so everything's programmer UI until she's back to tell us how to make it Good.

also: you may have noticed that, for a few minutes, we were serving something we call "purple cohost". this occurs when our deploy process is slower than it should be and we end up running two versions of the application at the same time. we had work scheduled to change how our deploys work to prevent this, and we're moving that work up to Today since a minutes long purple cohost is kind of embarrassing.
that's it for now! thanks for using cohost! :eggbug:

shareTree.plainTextBody:

that's it for now! thanks for using cohost! :eggbug:

shareTree.headline: everyone talks about eggbug but no one talks about Zenk "Crawdad" Gulb, the cohost goblin who works in the uptime mines
tags: we work all day so the bug can play

markdown.content: he's down there all damn day while that bug is up here having a grand time. it's time to celebrate the creatures that make this site possible. let's hear it for Crawdad Gulb and everyone else like him.
